29.94.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
Simon Barr, UK Realtree Pro-staffer, is learning

37.36.text:
how to protect his pheasants from foxes. We
are off to Ireland to Birr Castle Game Fair

44.48.text:
where terrier work may be becoming a new Olympic
sport.

49.10.text:
First, if you ever get the call up and you
want to know what to do, here is definitive

55.21.text: guide to what is driven grouse.

66.34.text:
There is winged game and then there is winged
game. And then there is driven grouse - it

81.61.text:
is expensive - it is exclusive but with good
reason. Thousands of man hours go into creating

88.47.text:
a habitat that will allow these ground nesting
Stinger missiles to flourish. And someone

96.52.text:
Today we join a family-and-friend-day shoot
in Yorkshire. We are on Bransdale moor and

101.95.text:
are guests of the Wilkinson family. Their
estate and their shoot is managed by William

108.37.text:
Because we are involved 365 days a year at
Bransdale and on our other moors we therefore

114.62.text:
have such a tremendous involvement we make
sure that every single day does live up to

121.82.text:
Mark Osborne from William Powell is the man
who will be guiding us through the day - explaining

126.13.text:
the dos and the don'ts, butt ettiquette - no
tittering in the back row - and why grouse

133.09.text:
They are really the most extraordinary birds.
You get grouse mid September probably as soon

138.78.text:
as they see you lift your gun and they flare
away up so that where you have shot is not

143.79.text:
where the grouse are. Really amazing, an amazing
bird. Marvellous.

147.88.text:
Before a hard day's shooting there is a hearty
breakfast to be had at the recently refurbished

153.45.text:
Stoney Woods Manor. This amazing building
has been fitted out in preparation for shooting

159.21.text:
parties to come and have a ball... on the
moor and off it.

164.67.text:
There are nine bedrooms with day rooms and
dining rooms all with spectacular views across

172.08.text:
The moor itself is a 25 minute drive away
- delving deeper into an uninterrupted moorland

178.48.text: landscape. It truly is a privilege to be here.

182.23.text:
There are nine guns today and five drives
where the birds come at you at eye level,

186.08.text:
so there's safety. There are people everywhere.
For this first one we're letting Mark get

188.54.text:
his eye in before we start badgering him about
how one does things.

216.57.text:
Mark shoots four birds - the end of the line
does not often deliver the best shooting but

221.32.text:
he has done well. Dogs and beaters make sure
that all the grouse on the ground are accounted

227.82.text:
The second drive is a bit more exposed and
we should be able to see the birds coming

231.69.text:
at us from a distance. Mark is now in butt
three.

237.33.text:
Mark has a chance to talk us through the set
up... the action can be fast and furious.

242.89.text: Safety is the number one concern.

244.95.text:
The first thing I do is to look around me
to see the topography, the line of the butts

252.16.text:
on either side and the good shooting angle
in front of me and then behind. The gun comes

259.21.text:
out of the sling we put the gun in front of
the butt with 2 cartridges in the gun so that

263.46.text:
we are ready, because we are live at any time
everybody is in their butts so we can shoot

268.85.text:
whenever it is safe and the grouse are coming.
We then get our butt sticks and our butt sticks

278.13.text:
are positioned by the gun rather than by the
loader and these are a frame that make sure

284.80.text:
that we cannot shoot into the butts either
side. So I look to see where a safe place

293.19.text:
to shoot and it is to stop there so the butt
stick has a window there which prevents us

299.67.text:
from shooting through into the butt on that
side. Then we take the other butt stick out

306.73.text:
to do the same on the other side. We have
got some flankers right up on the ridge there.

314.01.text:
They are probably out of shoot, but just to
be careful we will put a walking stick in

318.81.text:
front so there is no chance of us peppering
a fl

321.66.text:
anker either. The flankers are flagmen running
outside from the end butts, butt number one

328.22.text:
and butt number eight on either end and they
are to keep the grouse coming in as the drive

334.19.text:
Once the beaters get to a white marker in
front of the guns a horn blows telling the

338.66.text:
guns they can now only shoot birds behind
- to the rear of the butt. The beaters can

344.43.text: then come right up to the guns.

346.91.text:
A second horn means the end of the drive and
the birds can be picked. The guns should also

351.56.text:
use this disc to mark where the birds have
fallen.

356.22.text:
Time for a quick break... and an opportunity
for us to speak to the man who is shouldering

360.38.text:
a lot of the pressure today - the head game
keeper. For him this shoot is the culmination

366.97.text: of not months but years of work.

370.96.text:
This is the first big moor I have been a head
keeper on. I have been the head keeper on

374.24.text:
a small moor in Scotland. So coming here this
is the first moor I can really put my mark

381.20.text:
on and want to smash all records on Bransdale.
The record is 4,200 brace for the season and

391.62.text:
we would want to get it to 6. I would be very
disappointed if we didn't get it to 6. And

398.53.text:
also the day record although because it is
a let moor getting a team that is willing

403.09.text:
to pay for 500 brace of grouse could be quite
difficult. So that maybe is not as realistic

411.76.text:
a goal, but certainly the season record is
the one we want to go for.

417.36.text:
Yes, you have to. You wouldn't do it if you
didn't.

420.14.text:
Once fed and watered, there is more sport
to be had. For this third drive, we join one

425.12.text:
of the best game shots in the world. Simon
Ward. Simon used to compete very successfully

432.66.text:
on the clay circuit but now concentrates on
teaching sporting guns how to deal with a

437.03.text:
bird flying at just above ground level at
65mph.

442.81.text:
So as we have him cornered, it would be rude
not to ask him for a few pearls of wisdom.

448.04.text:
First of all it would be safety and the second
major tip would be learn to mount the gun

453.46.text:
accurately on to a moving object. In this
situation you have got grouse coming in at

459.88.text:
eye level and if you tend to stand too upright
and mount the gun with your head up in that

466.96.text:
position like so you are looking at the grouse
but the barrel will be beneath your eye. So

471.70.text:
the idea is that with anything at your eye
level or below you bring your head forwards

476.70.text:
so your balance comes over your front foot
and as you mount the gun on to the bird the

483.51.text:
gun comes up to the cheek naturally and when
it comes to crunch your lead eye, my left

493.55.text:
eye, is in effect the back sight. If I stand
too upright with my head up my eye will be

502.38.text:
in this position and as a consequence I will
be looking at the grouse up here and the barrel

507.37.text:
will be beneath my eye so I will shoot low.
So if you start with your head a little bit

514.50.text:
further forwards, nose over your toes and
then bring the gun up naturally to the eye,

521.35.text: now the gun will shoot where I look.

523.06.text:
We don't get much shooting but what does fly
past doesn't need a second barrel.

528.02.text:
Lunch means a three-course meal in this wonderful
carriage. Life is good and so is the food.

535.68.text:
And so is the shooting - for the penultimate
drive again we join Simon. This is the drive

583.64.text:
With the weather cooling, the birds are flying
really fast. Nothing gets past Simon.

592.94.text:
I am sure you can see from the film it was
all fairly exciting stuff and the grouse were

607.23.text:
whizzing around left, right and centre and
a few nice coveys coming through. We had to

612.32.text:
pick the right bird and set ourself up for
a left and right and one or two tricky ones

615.84.text:
out the back. You have seen it in the flesh
there. That is driven grouse shooting in all

624.77.text:
For the last drive, we are really pushing
the boat out. There is a chance of using a

628.50.text:
fourth barrel - sort of - Mark is shooting
a pair of William Powell Zenith side-by-sides.

635.08.text:
Why is it important to have good guns when
you are grouseshooting?

639.17.text:
To me it is lovely to shoot with a traditional
gun, the side by side. The design of these

644.21.text:
guns is based on Holland and Holland action
and it hasn't changed for about 100 years.

649.83.text:
So that actual design of that action is nearly
100 years old and Holland and Hollands are

655.79.text:
still made today exactly like that and there
is something really inherently wonderful about

661.35.text:
shooting with that traditional gun in this
very traditional environment.

666.97.text:
If there were a place where these deserve
an outing it is here and Mark believes that

671.57.text:
a side by side is actually better suited to
grouse.

675.46.text:
When you are shooting high pheasants or partridges,
having that tremendous balance of that over

681.64.text:
and under which goes on a single plain and
doesn't flick about is a great advantage.

686.14.text:
When you are shooting a bird which is jinking
right to left and backwards and forward like

691.08.text:
a grouse will do, having a gun that you can
put into your shoulder and move it very quickly,

696.20.text:
a side by side is that gun and is probably
an advantage.

697.75.text:
With the odd covey coming through, the loader
and guns are busy - and Mark is once again

699.29.text:
having some sport. It has been a fabulous
day and we have bagged 102 brace.

706.27.text:
Grouse shooting is deep-seated in the fabric
of this country. It is high octane sport,

711.32.text:
that brings so many added benefits from conservation
to cash for rural communities, and there is

716.59.text:
a super social side whether you are gun or
a beater.

721.08.text:
If you want to book some grouse shooting or
would just like to find out more about the

725.00.text:
estates managed by William Powell, go to www.williampowellsporting.co.uk
and if you want to turn up with a pair of

732.17.text:
smart William Powell shotguns in the back
of your car - prices start at £7,500 for

737.81.text:
a pair of side by sides or £4,500 for a pair
of over-and-unders. For more information go

747.69.text:
Now from open moorland to a closed mind. It's
David on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

761.59.text:
A wildlife charity is claiming that shooting
magazines should join other kinds of magazines

766.99.text:
on the top shelf in news agents. Animal Aid
claims that lurid pro-violence content of

773.46.text:
country sports magazines could have a corrosive,
long lasting effect on impressionable young

778.43.text:
minds. Professor Peter Squires of the University
of Brighton goes on to say the magazines such

783.11.text:
as Shooting Times and the Field are a kind
of shooting porn. He clearly doesn't realise

787.86.text:
that both shooting porn and traditional porn
is readily available on the internet. Apparently.

794.86.text:
The Paraolympics are set to get under way.
The shooters are competing from the 30th August

800.08.text:
to the 6th September. Great Britains 12th
person team includes Di Coates in her 8th

806.08.text:
Paraolympic games and the 2008 gold medallist
Matt Skellern who may also win a medal for

812.62.text:
BASC is hosting a number of events to help
people improve their shooting skills. There

817.67.text:
are one day courses with classroom and practical
sessions with BASC staff and BASC accredited

822.96.text:
shotgun coaches. They cost £65 for a BASC
member and £100 for a non member and are

828.93.text:
being held all over England and Wales. Visit
www.BASC.org.uk

833.02.text:
And finally, Essex was briefly excited over
the weekend when there were reported sightings

839.44.text:
of a lion on the loose. However, police believe
it is a domestic cat.

845.44.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

855.82.text:
Next - it's all the fun of the fair the Irish
Game & Country Fair at Birr Castle, Co Offaly

860.97.text:
Now here's how to turn terrierwork into an
Olympic sport for Rio 2016. Birr Castle hosts

882.74.text:
the finals of the All-Ireland Hole Digging
competition.

886.70.text:
When I started the shows there was very little
to do. After the initial show when the thing

901.90.text:
was over. There was always plenty of banter
in the rings who can dig and who couldn't

906.45.text:
dig. We have had some varied comments over
this competition. One wee lad reckoned he

910.89.text:
was digging like his Granny that was his way
of spurring him on. It all comes down to digging

920.12.text:
towers. So it does. .....in northern Ireland
is to promote it in a good light on TV as

927.18.text:
we all know it is only promoted in a bad light
so it is our way of saying we are all a varied

936.19.text:
range of people there is nothing wrong with
it.

940.10.text:
Triumph again. 2 years in a row now, 2 years
in a row.

947.66.text:
From spades to guns. You could hear the bangs
of the shooting line during the hole-digging.

952.81.text:
The clay shoot at the Birr Castle game fair
is organised by the local pheasant shoot

957.43.text:
We are the hosts game keepers in the castle
here at Birr and we are hosting this clay

964.68.text: shooting on behalf of the clay game fairs.

966.55.text:
So you are more used to real pigeons than
clay pigeons.

969.96.text:
Oh yes. Well we are game shooters in heart
and we are doing this I suppose to support

975.77.text:
our shooting. We are predominantly pheasant
shooters and duck shooters. Well all forms

982.71.text:
Birr Castle attracts standholders from all
over Ireland. William Holmes runs his tackle

988.06.text:
and fishing business in Northern Ireland,
where it has been a bumper year for salmon

992.34.text:
It has been very very good up round Derry
and up round the County Derry end, the County

999.70.text:
Yes, with the .....system and the ......system.
There has been a few of them with quite a

1001.91.text:
few regulation changes this year where a few
rivers are total catch and release. A lot

1006.86.text:
of the rivers they have cut down on the number
of fish that people can take. That is really

1011.96.text:
a reaction to the number of rod caught salmon
over the last few years. The ban system has

1017.37.text:
gone totally catch and release so it has and
we saw the figures very much up.

1022.75.text:
Everyone here is a hunter, shooter, fisher,
in short, imbued with Irish spirit. Ireland

1029.42.text:
is a paradise for fieldsports enthusiasts.
But there is a threat on the horizon. Birr

1036.04.text:
this year sees a call to action by a new pro-hunting
group supported by all the major Irish fieldsports

1043.56.text:
RISE is the acronym for rural alliances which
is a movement of country sport organisations

1049.97.text:
and indeed other country organisations who
are concerned with how our way of life in

1055.78.text:
the countryside is being pressurised and even
being regulated out of existence and it is

1061.34.text:
a common popular uprising if you like of rural
Ireland in defence of its way of life.

1068.17.text:
Senior government officials insist the bill
is no threat to hunting in Ireland but, after

1072.94.text:
the English experience, the locals here are
taking no chances.

1077.71.text:
There is vast support which has been demonstrated
today by the RISE campaign the amount of feeling

1082.91.text:
out there in the rural communities that they
will not accept this change and people have

1087.06.text: to respect our livelihood and our heritage.

1092.17.text:
It has been another great show organised by
Great Game Fairs of Ireland. Philip Lawton

1099.49.text:
Shooting, hunting, fishing, dog work, fly
casting, giant telescopes, canon re-enactments,

1108.85.text:
medieval nasty pieces going around and butchering
each other in the arena - well at least there

1117.72.text:
Next Realtree TV Pro-Staffer Simon Barr is
protecting his pheasants from foxes.

1127.26.text:
The harvest is just about over now and it
is a critical time of year if you have got

1133.01.text:
pheasants on a farm. The young naive foxes
are still about and this will give us a perfect

1137.37.text:
opportunity now the crops have come off to
see if we can mop a few of them up before

1141.77.text: the pheasant shooting season starts proper.

1143.55.text:
I am out this evening with fox shooter Gary
Tate. He has got a couple of new pieces of

1148.53.text:
kit to see whether or not they will make any
difference on the foxing that he normally

1152.48.text:
does. It looks like quite an interesting contraption
you have got on top of the quad bike. What

1157.58.text: is going on here. What is it all about?

1159.76.text:
Well it is a shooting frame which I am trying
this year. It is manufactured by K & A Services

1165.88.text:
and I am giving it a go to see how I get on
with it. I usually use just a front mount

1170.33.text:
rest and throw myself over that, but with
this the idea is that you can shoot all around.

1176.89.text:
It has a place to rest your rifle when you
are not using it. It has a place to hang game

1181.84.text:
on the back of it as well if you are out rabbiting.
And for me the main advantage that I like

1187.55.text:
is the fact that I have got somewhere to put
my lamp when I am not holding it and not picking

1191.57.text:
up foxes so if I go on my own this does give
me the versatility to shoot on my own and

1197.54.text: to mount the lamp whilst I am taking the shot.

1200.70.text:
So what would you like me to do this evening
Gary?

1203.56.text:
Well tonight Simon I think all I would like
you to do is watch and see how I go about

1207.79.text:
doing things if I was out on my own and if
we do find a fox, I'll get set up, you pass

1212.98.text:
me the rifle, I'll take the shot. Hopefully
there is plenty out here, we should see some

1219.62.text: Do you think I might get a chance at a fox?

1221.69.text:
There could well be a chance of a fox or two,
I think. Yes.

1224.31.text:
Excellent, excellent.Ok, well why don't we
get set up and make for some foxes.

1232.10.text:
Tonight we are lamping only 2 large areas
of the same farm. Gary has already taken half

1237.60.text:
a dozen foxes off this stubble, but he knows
it promises more. There is even the chance

1242.51.text:
of an urban fox from the local village. The
quad bike is a great tool for this type of

1247.80.text:
work and we cover a lot of ground scanning
as we go for foxes and those deep ruts which

1252.97.text:
would make my life on the back of the quad
very uncomfortable.

1257.16.text:
A couple of fields on and we get our first
set of eyes. Gary barks to keep it interested

1262.19.text:
and starts calling with the lamp off the target.
I lower the lamp to the sitting fox to fully

1267.57.text:
illuminate it for Gary to see it through the
scope and the fox instantaneously drops. Here

1273.50.text:
it is again right to frame. It is a great
start.

1277.41.text: Quite small in the body isn't it?

1279.05.text:
It is quite small in the body. But for me
it is a pleasing result because being a vixen

1284.57.text:
this is going to go on. This is going to produce
more. The same philosophy I use and is used

1289.84.text:
within the deer world. If you want to control
deer numbers you shoot females you don't go

1294.46.text:
shooting males. The same goes for foxes. It
only takes one dog fox to cover another female.

1298.78.text:
Here we have got a vixen she is now out of
the breeding programme, so we have got a job

1305.48.text: And a very good shot Gary.

1308.48.text:
Many fox shooters choose ballistic tipped
bullets when after charlies. Tonight Gary

1313.41.text:
is using 243 ammunition loaded by a friend
of ours. He is using my new Blaser Professional

1319.01.text:
Success with its ergonomically designed pistol
grip stock.

1322.73.text:
These are 70 grain ballistic tip home loaded
rounds. The ballistic tip gives us a very

1328.45.text:
fast expanding bullet so what happens on impact
is that this polymer tip here is driven back

1336.26.text:
into the bullet forcing the bullet to rapidly
expand and lose as much energy inside the

1342.86.text:
animal as possible without penetrating through.
We are not looking for a blood track. We are

1347.47.text:
not looking for a bleeding hole. We are looking
for an instantaneous dead animal and this

1356.19.text:
We cover acres of ground. Gary knows the lay
of the land on this farm, so he could probably

1360.55.text:
drive blind folded, but it is sensible not
to. The badgers have dug some enormous sets.

1365.71.text:
The perfect trap for a quad bike. We light
up fox number 2. Gary once again decisively

1371.59.text: finds the target. This time it is a youngster.

1374.01.text: What have you managed to knock over there.

1377.84.text:
It is another vixen Simon, which pleases me.
This is definitely a cub. You can tell. Very,

1385.25.text:
very fluffy, furry coat as opposed to hair
- more fluff than hair. Definitely a cub.

1392.42.text:
Much, much smaller teeth. Almost pristine
condition.

1396.11.text:
And Gary that ballistic tip has literally
taken that fox apart hasn't it?

1402.28.text:
It would have felt absolutely nothing would
it?

1406.26.text:
Now it is my turn on the Blaser and I hope
there are still some ....targets for me to

1410.38.text:
have a shot at. On the next sweep we find
one. The quad multi make rest gives me a steady

1415.83.text:
shot and I have comfortably accounted for
another female.

1419.44.text: So what was that about 100 metres or so Gary?

1422.00.text:
It was about 100 metres away mate. It is nicely
shot. Straight through the neck. Good shot,

1427.54.text:
clean kill. Another vixen. This time quite
an older one. I would say very old actually.

1433.50.text:
Comparatively speaking tonight, I think everything
has been quite young, but this one is quite

1438.59.text: I am very, very pleased with that.

1441.80.text:
I tell you what the rest on the quad bike
made a massive difference, being able to rest

1446.12.text:
my right elbow, it was kind of bench rest
conditions to be able to take that shot. It

1450.97.text:
The reason why I put the rest on there was
because I have always been able to rest as

1454.69.text:
every one can on the front of the bike, on
a rest on the front of the bike, but you always

1458.04.text:
find if you are right handed that your elbow
is flapping around in the wind and that is

1462.40.text:
really what you are looking for that sort
of bench rest set up where you are absolutely

1466.84.text:
solid and then you know you are going to get
a good shot.

1468.77.text:
Yes. I mean I felt very comfortable there
when I took the shot.

1471.60.text: It was a good shot. Well done.

1473.28.text:
Having covered every field on this side of
the farm we hitch up and head off to the other

1477.44.text: side, a couple of miles away.

1479.55.text:
The pheasant release pens are located on this
part of the farm, so it is crucial we eliminate

1484.02.text:
as many foxes as possible. The first foxes
we spot make for cover and will not stand.

1491.03.text:
Gary thinks these animals know a little too
much and have been lamped unsuccessfully before.

1495.78.text:
We lift the lamp hoping they might drop their
guard, but to no avail. We drive through the

1500.43.text:
cover crop and again spot a fox which knows
the score. Eventually we get a response which

1505.52.text:
we all hoped for. The fox stops long enough
for me to shoot. Amazingly the lamp's beam

1510.59.text:
picks up the path of the bullet as it sent
across the field which you can clearly see.

1515.30.text:
It is a satisfying long walk to retrieve it.
Gary reckons it is about 180 metres which

1519.69.text:
I am very pleased with. It is a mature dog
fox.

1523.38.text:
Gary thank you very much. It has been a brilliant
evening. 4 foxes, 3 vixens and that last dog

1528.65.text: fox which I am particularly happy with.

1531.03.text: That was a very good fox.

1532.65.text:
It was a very good fox. 180 metres, nice and
steady and he dropped to the shot very, very

1539.40.text:
Yes, very pleased with that. So thank you
very much. I have learnt a huge amount this

1543.63.text:
evening about the way that you fox. The techniques
that you use. There were a few that weren't

1549.00.text:
Yes, if they are not going to stand, leave
them alone. Don't start taking wild shots

1553.24.text: at them because you won't get another chance.

1555.10.text: Yes, it is a delicate process isn't it?

1557.34.text: Yes. We left quite a lot this evening.

1560.57.text:
Yes. Very happy with it. It was a good evening.
Taking out the vixens I always think is worth

1567.19.text: while, they are the breeding animals.

1569.20.text:
So 3 to 1 ratio tonight. So Gary thank you
very much.

1576.27.text:
Foxing is such an important job. As a crafty
predator they can really impact a pheasant

1581.12.text:
shoot. So accuracy and commitment are needed
to outwit this most cunning of adversaries.

1587.07.text:
It is a hugely satisfying task when it goes
right and pleasing to know that many more

1591.20.text: birds will make it to the season.

1593.89.text:
If you like this show why not tune into Teamwild
TV to see my buddy Ian Harford on his latest

1599.43.text:
bow hunting adventure to Hungary where he
takes the monster boar at 8 yards.

1604.64.text:
If you enjoy shooting you will love the shooting
show. This week it is a call to action for

1609.89.text:
rim fire and airgun shooters. Episode 16 of
the shooting show is the pest control bonanza.

1616.64.text:
Byron Pace makes it a family matter as his
brother Daryl joins him to deal with rabbits

1621.46.text:
on a new shooting ground in the Angus Glens.
South of the border Byron is joined by Sporting

1627.64.text:
Rifle writer, Tony Megson, for airgun pest
control on a Yorkshire farm curbing the population

1633.87.text:
of pigeons that roost in the barn and contaminate
the feed. There is another big bag to be had

1639.27.text:
here provided the pair can avoid angering
the resident pigs.

1643.27.text:
If you are watching this on Youtube you can
click on the screen behind me to go straight

1651.09.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1657.41.text:
We start with Mark Gilchrist hanging out with
a beatiful girl. Star of the Scandinavian

1662.30.text:
hunting world Kristoffer Clausen joins Mark
for a day's pigeon and goose and, crucially,

1666.70.text:
he brings Kristine Thybo Hansen. Kristoffer
promises an actionpacked episode. Not that

1673.22.text:
We make fims for GunOnPegs but occcasionally,
they get hold of their own cameras. And here

1677.95.text:
they are with a pair of the new I-KAM glasses,
which puts the camera right between your eyes,

1682.74.text:
which makes for good filming when they are
doing the same with shot at pigeons. Love

1686.08.text:
the oldfashioned hessian pigeon hide. They
should get that listed.

1690.07.text:
The Arab spring saw North Africa join up on
YouTube en masse. And some of them are hunters.

1695.16.text:
Here is MNayyer from Tunisia showing off his
HPR and catching birds with it. Might not

1700.43.text:
be your bag but shows what the world is up
to.

1702.98.text:
It's open to argument but not with me. Top
of the saltwater flyfishing world is permit

1707.54.text:
- and here is AddictiveFishing spinning for
them. Dear me. Give him both barrels will

1712.83.text:
you James? But you do get to see plenty of
fish in this film, made off Boca Grande, Florida.

1716.90.text:
The new motto for KineticFishing is 'shut
up and fish'. Cannibals on the Hunt - Big

1721.69.text:
Perch Fishing in Midwater is a romp set to
rock and roll through catching five big perch,

1726.29.text:
from 1.2kg to 1.6kg (that's three to three-and-a-half
pounds), somewhere in Scandinavia. They shut

1734.69.text:
Roebuck hunting in Scotland is the kind of
holiday video anyone would be pleased to show.

1739.20.text:
OK, it's a bit wobbly but it's a great showcase
for a Czech stalker's trip to Britain's last

1743.62.text:
great wilderness. Bad news for VisitScotland,
he chooses the theme tune to The Last of the

1749.50.text:
Now for some good ol'd American knowhow. The
National Shooting Sports Federation offers

1753.79.text:
its definitive guide to shooting off anything
but prone with former Army Ranger sniper team

1758.36.text:
leader Ryan Cleckner. If you are American,
watch and learn from Shooting Positions in

1762.82.text:
the Field - NSSF Shooting Sportscast. If you
are from anywhere else, you will probably

1767.29.text:
find something wrong with it, but that's nationalism
for you.

1770.24.text:
Now it's hard to find anything wrong with
Doug and Regis Giles. : They are on a wild

1774.51.text:
boar hunt in Florida. These guys' homspun
enthusiasm is a big part of the American YouTube

1779.58.text:
hunting scene. Doug runs clashdaily.com, Regis
runs GirlsJustWannaHaveGuns.com and she is

1785.50.text:
is using a double rifle in 9.3x74 with some
success on a pineywood rooter.

1790.34.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1793.60.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,

Well if you are watching this on Youtube please

where you can subscribe to just this show
